title: 106_hr1895
content:
The "School Anti-Violence Empowerment Act" authorizes the Secretary of Education to provide grants to local educational agencies for crisis intervention programs and school safety enhancements. The Secretary awards grants to local educational agencies for school counselors and safety programs based on factors like violence prevention programs, crisis intervention needs, and financial need. The Education Act of 1965 ensures equitable distribution of grants among different regions and areas. The Secretary can reserve up to 1% for administrative costs. Eligible local educational agencies can receive grants for hiring school counselors and enhancing safety programs. SEC. 103. APPLICATIONS. Each local educational agency seeking a grant under this title must submit an application to the Secretary with a plan including descriptions of existing safety programs, proposed changes, new programs, financial need, and the need for crisis intervention counseling programs. The local educational agency must submit an application with a plan including descriptions of safety programs, proposed changes, new programs, financial need, and the need for crisis intervention counseling programs. Documentation regarding financial need is also required. Each local educational agency receiving a grant must provide an annual report to the Secretary detailing the use of funds for school safety programs or hiring school counselors. The report should include descriptions of new safety measures, changes to existing programs, and the number of counselors hired. The term "school counselor" refers to an individual with counseling competence in a school setting, holding state licensure, national certification, or a master's degree in school counseling. The term "school counselor" refers to an individual with counseling competence in a school setting, holding state licensure, national certification, or a master's degree in school counseling. (C) must have a master's degree in school counseling from an accredited program. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. "School safety" pertains to the safety of students, faculty, and school facilities from acts of violence. SEC. 106. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $700,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2000-2004. TITLE II--INCREASED COPS FUNDING. SEC. 201. INCREASED FUNDING FOR THE COPS PROGRAM. $1,500,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2000-2004 for cooperative partnerships between schools and police departments. SEC. 202. GRANT AUTHORITY. SEC. 202. GRANT AUTHORITY. Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended by removing subsection (k) and modifying subsection (i). TITLE III focuses on after-school and life skills programs for at-risk youth, with specified funding amounts for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. TITLE IV introduces a model program. TITLE IV--MODEL PROGRAM AND CLEARINGHOUSE

SEC. 401. MODEL PROGRAM.

    The Secretary of Education, with the Attorney General, will develop a violence prevention program for local educational agencies.

SEC. 402. CLEARINGHOUSE.

    A national clearinghouse will provide technical assistance on violence prevention programs to local educational agencies.
